When the hidden depths first unfolded, the nine qi steamed and stirred without cease; the mysterious transformation spread wide, the six voids flowed and turned without rest. Establishing the gate of the non-dual teaching, he examined the root of the True One. The vast wind blew across the sea, three revolutions reduced the world to flying dust; the kalpa-fire consumed the mountains, five cycles leveled them to flat earth. First he wandered in the Blue Eon—when the Blue Eon had run its course, later he emerged and vanished in the Red Radiance—when the Red Radiance too was complete.

Ninety-nine myriad billion years were stored in a pellet; five thousand five hundred layered heavens were concealed within an eggshell. At the time when High Ancestor Tang of Yin ascended the throne, when King Wen of Zhou first unfolded the *Yi*, divine radiance flowed into the jade womb, auspicious splendor knit into golden bones. Unsplit, unsevered, he gestated for more than eighty years; descending blessings and omens, he surpassed the span of twenty thousand days. His feet trod the principle of imperishability, his hands grasped the writ of long life. He embraced Qian and enfolded Kun, seized the sun and grasped the moon. His brow bore the stars of Shen and Wu, his crown upheld the round vault; his ears opened the Three Gates, his nose stood as twin pillars. His blood was white, his brain purple; his liver azure, his spleen green. His nape drew forth thirty-five rays, his teeth held forty-eight cowries. Seven-hued blue lotuses followed his steps, a thousand-year white deer presented their felicity.

Though mulberry fields changed, the twin cypresses never withered; though rivers ran dry, the nine wells never failed. In the village of Lai in Ku County, numinous traces endure; on the banks of Wo Spring in Chen State, divine footprints do not fade. Seven hundred disciples pointed to Fusang as their old grove; the Nine-Five Lord opened the Sun Palace as his former abode.

Tracing his primordial beginning, examining that earliest origin, he looked down upon the darkness before the Dark Ford, gazed below into the chaos after the Primal Undifferentiated. Adapting his teaching to the moment, he became the model for the Nine Ancients; responding to change without fixed method, he set the pattern for a hundred kings.

When the year began with Sheti, inaugurating the signs of qi, thirteen sages ascended the throne, fulfilling the chart of eighteen thousand years. Our Most High Mysterious Origin Sage Ancestor answered the moment and descended in manifestation, serving as teacher to the Heavenly Sovereign. At the first opening of the Upper Purity and Lower Turbidity, the separation was not distant; at the sudden rending of the Six Directions and Eight Cords, the division was not far. He set right the forms of square and round, above and below; he determined the state of vast primeval simplicity. Rivers newly melted yet waters remained murky; mountains first congealed yet stones were not yet firm. He sowed the white elms of heaven, which first sprouted in rows; he planted the green osmanthus of the moon, which just then grew in clusters. He matched the Four Seas to the Four Spirits, entrusted the Five Phases to the Five Emperors.

At that time, the image of Qian still hung low, the form of Kun remained thin. Establishing the pole and fixing positions, he spread transformation and built merit. Our Most High Sage Ancestor condescended to descend, serving as teacher to the Earthly Sovereign. Allotting hard and soft, he instituted cold and heat; the earth grew broader and thicker, the sky higher and brighter. His sagely power was unfathomable, his divine work inscrutable. Ten thousand trees split their husks, ten thousand grasses hooked their sprouts. Feathered flocks and furred herds were distinguished in the positions of Dui and Li; shelled creatures and scaled kinds were divided in the palaces of Kan and Zhen. The waters of the Four Directions were all empty—fish and turtles not yet born; the forms of the Five Peaks were all still—clouds and mist not yet exhaled.

Having passed the years of the Clear Sea, he departed from the age of the Clear Sea. When the Two Sages had governed, the Four Quarters shone with light. Our Most High Sage Ancestor broadly bestowed and saved the multitude, serving as teacher to the Human Sovereign. The three hundred sixty rivers first divided their veins; the eleven thousand five hundred stalks just then matched odd and even. The gods of Three Ren and Three Yi departed the womb of water and wood; the generals of Six Bing and Six Xin emerged from the gestation of fire and wind. For one hundred fifty-six generations, forty-five thousand years, he was first called Master of the Mysterious Dao, then titled Lord Emperor of the Golden Gates. His three names were Master Pan Gu.

When Fuxi ruled all under heaven, our Most High Sage Ancestor, to broadly save with the Dao, descended in manifestation as his teacher. Gazing up at the patterns of the round canopy, looking down at the principles of the square earth, he taught him to draw the Eight Trigrams, instructed him in the division of the Three Powers. He aided him in creating written characters to replace knotted cords, in establishing governance to succeed the age of tying knots. The *Three Ritual Classics* and *Five Canons* issued from him, the classics and scriptures arose from him. In hunting and fishing, he took the image of the bright Li; in the first and second divinations, he employed the work of the issuing Zhen. Phoenixes presented auspices in the imperial court; the dragon-horse bore the chart on the Yellow and Luo Rivers. He reigned for eighteen thousand years.

When Lianshan ruled all under heaven, our Most High Sage Ancestor, to save the age, humbled himself and descended as imperial teacher. He entrusted him with the Five Movements, divided for him the Four Seasons. He aided him in ordering the ten thousand affairs, enlightened him in distinguishing the hundred grains. He transformed the age of drinking blood and eating raw flesh, shifted the sound of earthen drums and clay chimes. He destroyed caves and burned nests, raised beams above and built eaves below. He smelted metal and molded clay, cooked millet and split piglets. He fashioned plows to aid the multitudes, made pottery to benefit the myriad things. Heaven rained grain to present auspices, earth sprouted crops to display abundance. People ate fine grains, mountains produced tools and chariots.

When the Lord of Youxiong ruled all under heaven, our Most High Sage Ancestor concealed himself within Kongtong, released his mind beyond the distant dark. The emperor personally descended in his carriage, offering rites to honor the teacher-disciple bond. He hastened to the corner in tattered robes, then bent his knees to inquire of the Dao. At that time, the tyrant of Yu Gang oppressed, Chiyou rebelled. He transformed fish and turtles into soldiers to aid the royal army, changed clouds and mist into spirits to secretly assist the battle lines. He ended war at Zhuolu, stilled weapons at Banquan. He bound the roaming to the land of Qingqiu, reached north to the scene of Hongti. He received the cinnabar scriptures at Wangwu, ascended the azure void at Dinghu. The bending plant sprouted, the divine beans reappeared—if not for the Great Dao, who could achieve this?

When the Lord of Jintian ruled all under heaven, inheriting the source of the Ji River and the records of Xiong Mountain, he announced to heaven and emulated the emperor, drilling into the thread to uphold the texts.

chunks.original_text: 我太上圣祖乘九龙之辇，降以为师、号太极先生，说庄敬之典，教之以顺时迎气，昭配神明，里于六宗，秩於群望，乾乾翼翼，得礼之宜。 羽族呈休，命之以乌官为理，分布九鸟，以统百司，景合璧以表灵，凤衔图而示既，悉由至道，彰此帝谟。 逮至高阳氏之王天下也，我太上圣祖教之以解纷塞兑，治国安民，涤荡九黎，陆明八凯，有龙野紫髯之凶丑，有蛇身赤发之渠魁，力拔不周，首触山碎，天侃西北，致日月之西行，地亚束南，使江海而东注。 追呼六甲，役御百灵，训之以微言之经，教之以大顺之道。 乘玄虹之迅驾，或适幽陵，御素璃以遐游，或臻蟠木。 观吾仙棣，万年而一度开花，睹我灵瓜，四劫而一回结实。 及乎高辛氏之王天下也，我太上圣祖敷道布化，济代为师，谭黄庭之妙言，隐日遁月，称录图之嘉号，返邑移城。 制九州之名，作六英之乐，封勾芒以佐苍帝，劲募收以翼白方，封岱岳而印金泥，昭一寰区而开玉镜，饮大活之井，游不夜之乡，墦青鸾之膏，充下仙之次撰，擘黄麒之脯，为上客之珍羞。 逮至陶唐氏之王天下也，我太上圣祖暂垂至理，下降为师，讲玄德之经道，以匡於玄化，应丹陵之瑞名，冀列於丹丘，和煦清风，不作呜条之响，雍熙黄发，时闻击壤之声。 庖厨之肉脯自生，载肴失味，山谷之醴泉潜涌，麴蘗无功。 达四聪以辟四门，立五事而敷五教，披鹿裘以食蛎饥，端拱於土阶，挂鹤氅而饮流霞，凝思於瑶圃。 有虞氏之王天下也，我太上圣祖谭无为之理，讲离合之经，三苗克俊，四罪咸服，百揆时序，五典慎徽。 怀明神之珠，赐昭华之玉。 眉与发等，表践祚之嘉祥，寿与天齐，彰延龄之景福。 甄一十六相，用二十五臣，致百辟以协和，如鱼在水，感兆人之归奏，如蚁慕擅。 化灵气为天书，何劳笔力，结卿云为宝殿，不假人工。 夏后氏之王天下也，我太上圣祖克匡王道，爰作帝师，谭德戒之经，行为国之法。 栉沐风雨，刊搓山林，成九年理水之功，为四载勤王之业。 卑宫陋室，尽力於沟洫之时，褴服缕衣，饰身於．衬冕之礼，导马颊而奔流竹箭，凿龙门而迅激桃花。 救兆庶而皆免为鱼，济陆土而永非成海，胸罗玉斗，挂天文之在躬，手展瑶图，悬国命之由己。 故知大道者，三教之冠冕，上德者，百圣之宗元。 成汤氏之王天下也，我太上圣祖权离左极，下为王师，说长生之经、体自然之道，去三面之网，开一目之罗，兽远逝而莫萦，禽高翔而不买。 引万方而罪己，数六事以责躬，话之以八素七真，讲之以六虚十诀，千岁桃花之蜜，味掩朱浆，九垓蓝叶之蔬，滋沾红露。 乘三光而电转，驾六气以烟腾，窥海渍如涓涔，视嵩衡如茧栗。 餐风饮露，跨空摄虚，以十洲为少游之宫，以六极为暂别之馆。 驱偶中士，役试下仙，素发一茎，悬起万斤之石，绿筠数尺，变成百丈之龙。 得之者七祖超升，失之者一身迷俟。 必在坚修慎习，弃苦忘辛，可以陶冷二仪，涎坛九土。

Our Most Supreme and Sacred Ancestor descended in a chariot drawn by nine dragons, assuming the role of teacher and styled as Master of the Great Ultimate. He expounded the canons of solemn reverence, instructing in the rites of aligning with the seasons and welcoming the qi, luminously matching the numinous powers, honoring the Six Ancestral Spirits, and conducting sacrifices to the host of sacred sites. With ceaseless diligence and awe, he attained the proper measure of ritual. The feathered tribes displayed their auspiciousness, and he appointed them to govern as the Avian Officials, distributing the Nine Birds to oversee the hundred bureaus. Radiance conjoined with jade to manifest numinosity, and the phoenix bore the celestial chart in proclamation—all through the supreme Dao, which revealed this imperial design.

When the High Lord of Yang ruled all under heaven, our Most Supreme and Sacred Ancestor taught him to resolve conflicts and unblock obstructions, to govern the state and pacify the people. He swept away the Nine Li tribes, illuminating the Eight Virtues. There were the savage brutes with wild purple beards, the chieftains with serpentine bodies and crimson hair—so mighty they uprooted Mount Buzhou, their heads shattering the peaks. Heaven tilted to the northwest, causing the sun and moon to course westward; earth sank in the southeast, making the rivers and seas flow eastward. He summoned the Six Jia spirits, commanded the hundred numina, instructing them in the subtle-worded scriptures and teaching them the Dao of Great Compliance. Mounting a swift chariot of dark rainbow, he journeyed to the hidden mounds; riding a pale-glass carriage, he roamed afar to the coiled trees. Beholding our immortal catalpa, which blooms but once in ten thousand years, and gazing upon our sacred gourd, which bears fruit but once in four kalpas.

When the High Lord of Xin ruled all under heaven, our Most Supreme and Sacred Ancestor spread the Dao and disseminated transformation, aiding the age as its teacher. He discoursed on the wondrous words of the *Huangting*, concealing the sun and eluding the moon; he proclaimed the auspicious titles of the celestial charts, shifting cities and relocating settlements. He established the names of the Nine Provinces, composed the *Six Elegances* music, enfeoffed Goumang to assist the Azure Emperor, and summoned Rushou to aid the White Realm. He sealed Mount Tai with golden mud, illuminating the entire realm as if unveiling a jade mirror. He drank from the Well of Great Vitality, wandered the Land of Unending Day, anointed himself with the grease of the green simurgh to sustain the ranks of lesser immortals, and carved the flesh of the yellow qilin to serve as delicacies for exalted guests.

When the Lord of Tao and Tang ruled all under heaven, our Most Supreme and Sacred Ancestor briefly bestowed the perfect principles, descending to serve as teacher. He expounded the scriptures of mysterious virtue to rectify the profound transformation, responding to the auspicious name of Crimson Mound in hopes of joining the ranks of Crimson Mound. Gentle and harmonious, the clear breeze made no sound at Wutiao; radiant and joyful, the yellow-haired elders were heard playing the *jiqiang* game. Meat and jerky in the kitchens grew of their own accord, rendering seasonings superfluous; sweet springs welled forth in the valleys, rendering fermentation useless. He opened the Four Gates to extend the Fourfold Wisdom, established the Five Affairs, and disseminated the Five Teachings. Donning a deer-fur robe, he ate oysters to assuage hunger; seated upright upon the earthen steps, he composed his thoughts. Wearing a crane-feather cloak, he drank the flowing rosy clouds, meditating in the Jasper Gardens.

When the Lord of Yu ruled all under heaven, our Most Supreme and Sacred Ancestor discoursed on the principle of non-action and expounded the scriptures of separation and union. The Three Miao tribes were subdued, the Four Offenders all submitted. The hundred offices followed their seasons, and the Five Canons were observed with care. He bestowed the luminous divine pearl and granted the radiant *zhaohua* jade. His brows and hair were of equal length, signifying the auspicious omen of his reign; his lifespan matched that of heaven, manifesting the glorious blessing of extended years. He discerned the sixteen ministers and employed the twenty-five officials, bringing the hundred lords into harmony as fish in water, and inspiring the myriad people to submit like ants drawn to sweetness. He transformed the numinous qi into celestial script, sparing the labor of brushwork, and wove auspicious clouds into a jeweled palace, requiring no human craft.

When the Lord of Xia ruled all under heaven, our Most Supreme and Sacred Ancestor aided the royal Dao, becoming the emperor’s teacher. He expounded the scriptures of virtue and admonition, setting the model for the state. He combed through wind and rain, hewed through mountains and forests, completing the nine-year task of regulating the waters and fulfilling the fourfold duty of serving the king. Though his palace was humble and his chambers mean, he devoted himself to the work of ditches and canals; though his garments were tattered and his robes threadbare, he adorned himself with the rites of cap and sash. He guided the Majie River to rush like bamboo arrows and chiseled Dragon Gate to hasten the peach-blossom currents. He saved the multitudes from becoming fish and ensured the dry land would never become a sea. His breast cradled the jade Dipper, bearing the celestial patterns upon his person; his hands unfurled the jasper chart, holding the mandate of the state within himself.

Thus it is known: the Great Dao is the crown of the Three Teachings, and supreme virtue is the origin of the hundred sages. When the Lord of Tang ruled all under heaven, our Most Supreme and Sacred Ancestor temporarily departed the leftmost pole, descending to serve as the king’s teacher. He expounded the scriptures of longevity and embodied the Dao of natural spontaneity, removing the three-sided nets and opening the one-eyed snares. Beasts fled far and were no longer ensnared; birds soared high and were not trapped. He summoned the myriad regions to blame himself, enumerating six faults to reproach his own conduct. He discoursed on the Eight Simplicities and Seven Perfections, expounded the Six Voids and Ten Secrets. The honey of the thousand-year peach blossoms surpassed crimson nectar in flavor; the greens of the ninefold blue leaves were drenched in rosy dew. Mounting the Three Luminaries, he turned swift as lightning; riding the Six Qi, he soared like mist. Gazing upon the sea, it seemed but a droplet; beholding Mount Song and Mount Heng, they appeared as silkworm cocoons and millet grains. Feasting on wind and drinking dew, he traversed the void and grasped the formless. He took the Ten Continents as his minor palaces and the Six Poles as his temporary lodgings. He drove the immortals of the middle realm and employed the lesser transcendents for trials. A single strand of white hair could lift a ten-thousand-*jin* stone; a few feet of green bamboo could transform into a hundred-*zhang* dragon. Those who attained it saw their seven ancestors ascend; those who lost it remained deluded in their single lifetime. It lies only in steadfast cultivation and careful practice, forsaking bitterness and forgetting toil—thus one may refine the Two Modes and moisten the Nine Lands.

chunks.original_text: 青羊肆者，按本纪则太上玄元大帝第二降生之所。 自殷道否闭，周德凌夷，陆海沸腾，百川振动，山呜谷吼，雨啸风号，历藏史以同尘，弃柱史而隐迹。 束离魏阙，西度函关，乘青牛宛转之车，驾白凤逍遥之辈，徐甲执御，从仙帝以爰来，尹喜占风，知道君之必至。 暂别而三千甲子曾作赤童，相逢而八百年龄永依黄老。 潜传妙诀，暗付微言，重为千日之期，再结一时之会。 暂朝元始，却上天中之天，永奉宗师，重归象外之象，开寒灵之丹殿，登众宝之琼台，坐紫金之林，托碧琳之机。 太清仙伯，仗星光锦文之旗，大极仙公，执月华命神之节，皆拜首稽首，以心观心。 於是劫青帝之青童，化羊於蜀国，乘紫云於紫府，降瑞於王官。 将停不嘎之声，须及来斯之乳，俄闻喜至，顿止婴啼，爰从赤子之身，却变白头之士，顷刻而身余十尺，须臾而面放五光，头建七曜玲珑之冠，肩垂九色离罗之被，卫士逾亿，从仙成群，感十方之众真，褊满寥廓，应八表之瑞气，充塞虚空，香散九微之烟，花飞六出之雪。 将离蜀土，欲化胡风，远适流沙，长移犷俗，及身毒厨宾之国，教烦陀阿柱之王，恣刚强愎戾之心，起烹焚錾刺之意，巨锜燃汤以沸地，我则入之如冻泉，积薪烈火以连天，我则坐之如钳雾，挟白挺者观如蓬草，持赤刃者视若铅刀，四天之兵众俱来，声喧霆霹，万里之神祇共护，力转山河，八十种之埙戎，皆归清化，二千国之犷捍，永革昏风。 俗既变矣，道既成矣，分身作佛，济如来千劫之功，降迹为师，救王者万机之务。 至若铜浑测运，玉历推祯，天七五而一三及九乃满，地八六而二四到十乃盈，变通阳九之灾，穷研百六之数，虽玄羲轩昊之代，无以免斯，高辛唐虞之朝，不能避此。 粤以广明元祀，岁在上章，月当大蛤，巨猾开誉於天邑，渠魁淑扰於国步，兵缠九野，群臣咸议於省方，蛇起陆风，四岳齐迎於巡狩，长鲸呀口，闻饮澧吐镐之声，封豕横牙，冲列刃钻锥之队，牛虻未搏，食吾黎庶之膏，象蚁未除，穴我楼台之地，尘蒙华盖，盗梗天衢。 九龙齐驾於云舆，玉轮西转，万乘同迥於坤轴，金阙南开，涉水则波神捧舟，登陆则地祇扈跸，太玄城内，化出行宫，濯锦江边，权安正殿，执玉帛者数盈万国，列鸳鹭者位满千官，鹅林之群来朝，鳌山解缆，鹤拓之城入贡，象驾来王。 当戎夷率服之辰，成文轨混同之日，苗人未格，方资益赞之谋，扈氏延诛，正赖胤师之力，熊韬豹韬之将，俯立军功，龙角羊角之山，可追圣瑞。 二十八化，犹乘白鹿而来，一百六灾，必跨苍此而救。 港扶宗社，幽赞子孙，赤光照灼於庭台，太平显兆，紫气晶荧於梅筱，元吉尤彰。 稽彼变通，明兹感应，寻其灵迹，果获实饭，上有古篆文日：太上平，中和灾。 於是验其六字，表此百祥，击之即声类鸣嘐，观之则状如弘璧，历周、秦、汉、魏之代，玉篆仍新，经晋、宋、梁、隋之朝，银钩不故，藏诸辊匮，秘甚缄滕，克盛皇猷，显标青史。 岁代绵邈，疆井变移，旧址苔封，古坛芜役，仙乡故里，半落俗家，真境余风，惟残瓦砾。 枯松夜月，移闻玄鹤之声，暮草秋烟，空听莎鹦之响。 当时云洞，多隐狐狸，昔日芝田，尽生禾黍。

The Green Ram Market, according to the *Annals*, was the site of the Supreme Dark-Primal Great Emperor’s second descent into the world. When the Yin Dao was obstructed and the Zhou virtue declined, the land-sea seethed and the hundred rivers surged; mountains roared and valleys howled, rain shrieked and wind wailed. He traversed the ages as dust in the historian’s records, then abandoned the pillar-scribe’s post to conceal his traces. Binding his robes, he departed the Wei Gate and crossed west through the Han Pass, riding a carriage drawn by a green ox in graceful turns, driving a white phoenix in carefree flight. Xu Jia held the reins as he followed the Transcendent Emperor in arrival; Yin Xi divined the winds and knew the Dao Lord must come. Though briefly parted, three thousand *jiazi* cycles had once made him a crimson youth; though reunited, eight hundred years of age now clung to the Yellow and the Old. Secretly he transmitted the wondrous formulas, silently he entrusted the subtle words, renewing the thousand-day covenant and reconvening the one-hour assembly.

For a moment he paid homage to the Primal Beginning, then ascended to the Heaven within Heaven. Forever he served his ancestral master, returning once more to the form beyond forms. He opened the Cold Numinous Elixir Palace, ascended the Jeweled Terrace of All Treasures, sat in the Purple-Gold Grove, and reposed upon the Azure-Jade Throne. The Transcendent Earl of Grand Clarity bore the star-embroidered brocade banner; the Transcendent Duke of Great Ultimate wielded the moon-bright spirit-summoning staff. All bowed their heads and prostrated, contemplating mind with mind.

Thereupon he summoned the Azure Lad of the Azure Emperor, transformed into a ram in the land of Shu, rode the purple clouds to the Purple Palace, and descended auspicious omens upon the royal chambers. The sound of his unceasing voice reached the newborn’s cry; in an instant, the infant’s wailing ceased. From the body of a crimson child he reverted to a white-haired elder. In a moment his stature exceeded ten feet; in an instant his face radiated fivefold light. Upon his head he wore a crown of the Seven Luminaries wrought in openwork; from his shoulders draped a nine-hued mantle of gossamer silk. His guards numbered beyond a hundred million; his transcendent retinue formed throngs. The assembled Perfected of the Ten Directions filled the vast expanse; the auspicious vapors of the Eight Extremities suffused the void. Fragrance wafted from the ninefold subtle flames; flowers drifted like six-pointed snow.

About to depart Shu, he sought to transform the barbarian winds, journeying far to the Flowing Sands to reform the savage customs. In the lands of India and Kabul, he taught King Fan-tuo and King A-zhu, curbing their stubborn and perverse hearts, dispelling their intent to boil, burn, chisel, and pierce. When vast cauldrons seethed with bubbling water, he entered as though stepping into frozen springs; when pyres of piled wood blazed to the heavens, he sat as though enveloped in mist. Those who brandished white cudgels saw them as withered reeds; those who wielded red blades found them dull as lead. The armies of the Four Heavens advanced with thunderous clamor; the deities of ten thousand *li* shielded him, their power shifting mountains and rivers. The eighty kinds of Qiang and Rong submitted to pure transformation; the two thousand lands of fierce savagery forever abandoned their benighted ways.

Once customs were transformed and the Dao accomplished, he divided his body to become a buddha, aiding the Tathāgata’s thousand *kalpas* of merit; he descended in traces to become a master, relieving the king’s myriad affairs of state. As for the bronze armillary measuring the heavens and the jade calendar reckoning auspiciousness: when heaven’s seven, five, one, three, and nine cycles reached completion, and earth’s eight, six, two, four, and ten cycles attained fulfillment; when the disasters of the Nine Yangs were exhausted and the reckonings of the Hundred Sixes thoroughly probed—even in the eras of Fu Xi, Shen Nong, and the Yellow Emperor, none could escape these, nor could the courts of Gao Xin, Tang, and Yu avoid them.

In the first year of Guangming, the year *shangzhang* in the cycle, the month of the great clam, a great villain rose to fame in the imperial capital, and a chief brigand disturbed the kingdom’s course. Weapons entwined the nine wilds; all ministers counseled the emperor to inspect the provinces. Serpents arose in the land winds; the four peaks welcomed the imperial progress. The long whale gaped, its roar drinking the waters of Li and spouting those of Hao; the boar with tusks like swords charged the ranks of blades and awls. Before the gadflies could strike, they devoured the fat of our people; before the ants could be eradicated, they burrowed into the foundations of our towers. Dust shrouded the imperial canopy; bandits blocked the celestial thoroughfares.

Nine dragons drew the cloud chariot as the jade wheel turned west; ten thousand chariots circled the earth’s axis as the golden gates opened to the south. Crossing waters, the wave spirits bore the boat; ascending land, the earth deities escorted the imperial cortege. Within the Great Mystery City, a traveling palace manifested; beside the Brocade-Washing River, the main hall was temporarily established. Those bearing jade and silk numbered myriad states; those arrayed in ranks of mandarin ducks filled a thousand offices. The flocks of Goose Forest came to court; the Turtle Mountain loosed its moorings. The cities of Crane Marsh presented tribute; the elephant-drawn carriages of foreign kings arrived.

At the time when the Rong and Yi submitted in compliance, when the tracks of carts merged and the world was united—when the Miao people had not yet been pacified, requiring the aid of sagely counsel; when the Hu clan prolonged its punishment, relying on the strength of the imperial teacher—generals versed in the *Bear Stratagems* and *Leopard Stratagems* bowed to military merit; the Dragon-Horn and Ram-Horn mountains could trace their sacred omens. Twenty-eight transformations still rode the white deer to arrive; the hundred-six disasters must be met astride the azure steed to save.

He propped up the ancestral altars and aided the imperial descendants in secret. Crimson light blazed upon the palace halls, heralding the advent of Great Peace; purple vapors glowed upon the plum and bamboo, presaging supreme felicity. Examining these transformations, he illuminated their responses; tracing his numinous traces, he indeed obtained the solid rice. Above was an ancient seal-script inscription: *The Supreme Brings Peace, the Center Harmonizes Disasters.* Thereupon he verified the six characters, manifesting a hundred auspicious signs. Struck, it resounded like the cry of a phoenix; beheld, it resembled a vast jade disc. Through the ages of Zhou, Qin, Han, and Wei, the jade script remained fresh; through the dynasties of Jin, Song, Liang, and Sui, the silver hooks showed no decay. Stored in layered caskets, sealed with utmost secrecy, it glorified the imperial enterprise and emblazoned the green histories.

As the years and generations stretched distant and the boundaries of fields shifted, the old site became overgrown with moss, the ancient altar lay in ruins. The immortal homeland and former abode now half belonged to common households; the remnants of the true realm’s winds lingered only in broken tiles and scattered rubble. Beneath the withered pines in the night moon, one might still hear the cries of dark cranes; amid the autumn grasses and evening mist, one could but listen to the echoes of thrushes in the sedge. The cloud caves of that time now sheltered foxes and hares; the mushroom fields of old had all grown millet and grain.

chunks.original_text: 遐追灵迹，显验休祯。 皇帝特下明诏，创造灵宫，恩赐内外，行库钱二百万爰征班匠，乃速厥功。 於是木神送材，九层崇构，地祇献土，百堵俱兴，水伯进泉以为池，山灵走石而作础。 巍峨云阁，乍似化成，岌〝 素霞堂，初疑涌出。 檐张羽翼，栋压虹蜕，粉壁霜凝，丹楹火亘，窗笼倒景、户辟长霄，塑像新成，仪形乍降，神情欲语，似讲五，千之文，意貌将行，远化十方之士，金炉芬馥，宝伞回旋，乍睹出槛之羊，犹疑跪乳，初观如练之马，尚虑嘶风。 庭剪蓬茅，重生瑶草，园除萱模，再吐琼花。 冈阜崔鬼，楼台显敞，齐束淇圆娇之殿，抗西极化人之宫。 牵剑阁之灵威，尽归行在，簇峨媚之秀气，半入都城。 烟枯碧坛，风引清磬，故得五老下降，四真俱来，画地而成其江湖，撮土而作其山岳，坐致风雨，可以倒洛倾河，立起云烟，可以反昼作夜，化草木以成军旅，变士马以成丛林，如斯出师，岂惟百胜，如斯伐叛，何啻七擒。 是以天灾流行，尽彼盈虚之理，历数倚伏，禀其否泰之宜。 左慈呼召于神兵，鞭笞群盗，许逊指挥于力士，剪荡狂妖。 所以阴伦兆人，弥纶万圣，郊瞒丹水，屡陈诚告之功，牧野昆肠，累献遗俘之捷，戈甲耀乎八水，营垒塞乎四郊，阵势云横，军声雷动，血洒空而骤雨赤，沙胀野而飘云黄。 困兽摧牙，长蛇畏尾，郊郑人之霄溃，观楚幕以尽空，德均而义士致身，气直而王师难老，度日而长呜金鼓，曾不告劳，终年而不解铁衣，未尝言苦。 既而凤城光复，龙德昭明，枉矢当弦，穿月之功奚用，长竿在手，撞天之势何为。 遂至修统脱泉，狂兕入匣，师道运末，断领於赤心之徒，禄山数穷，劈腹於苍头之辈。 况逆巢干纪，悖气凌空，呜蝼蝈七八余龄，聚豺狼数十万众，伤残九土，凌犯二京。 盖因祝天网以缓诛，布仁风而宽戮，遂偷生之五载，并除恶於一时。 蚩尤之冢既成，坚埋铁额，长狄之喉已断，永戢雕戈。 立此神功，实资道力，我太上金阙玄元天皇太帝，为天地父母，作帝王宗师，历教三皇，皆万八千岁，侯乎四气，交会五运，合同国位，永付於子孙，圣祚上齐於日月，克绍万八千之岁矣。 我高祖神尧皇帝，应天受命，历数在躬，以乡观乡，去仙乡之无远，上德不德，增帝德以弥高。 辍九赤之班符，封山印海，追八景之仙辖，辗雾盘云，负康垂旎，当阳阐化。 我太宗文武皇帝，握乾阐坤，修文偃武，大礼无体，百礼而尽执根元，大音希声，一声而振动今古。 天赐勇智，挚虎豹如束刍，神助皇威，铨蛟璃如结蚓。 还真返素，游艺依仁，以无绳为绳，缚六雄与五霸，以不器为器，笼四侮与九州。 然后争於不争，则战争而永息，欲於不欲，则嗜欲而长消。 方士众臻，真公来格，安期之枣异状，大若瓠瓜，园客之茧殊形，磊如盆盎，垂衣一百五十代，享国一万八千年。 伏惟圣神聪睿仁哲明孝皇帝陛下，克绍丕图，统兹大业，心县寿镜，身享福庭。 帝道中兴，国根深固，永保神器，长正皇纲。 虎牙将军，领八千之勇士，龙头元帅，提百万之精兵、永以镇定区中，永以削平天下。 巨鳌毙而形躯塞海，长鲸戮而警鬣插天。 或炙或焚，尽千山之木，以烹以饪，竭五湖之泉，紫焰腥膻，青萍膏血，祆日堕落，孛星陨坠，苍昱开豁，黑气消亡，献巨逆之三颅，告行朝之九庙，耀武威於英代，立京观於神州。

Pursuing afar the numinous traces, their wondrous proofs stood manifest. The Emperor specially issued a luminous edict to construct a sacred palace, bestowing upon both inner and outer courts two million strings of cash from the treasury to summon artisans and hasten the work. Thereupon the wood spirits delivered timber, and a nine-tiered towering structure arose; the earth deities offered soil, and a hundred walls simultaneously took form. The water lords advanced springs to fashion pools, while the mountain spirits hastened stones to lay foundations. Lofty cloud-piercing pavilions seemed to have sprung forth by transformation; the soaring Jade Mist Hall appeared as though newly risen from the earth. Eaves spread like wings, and beams pressed down like molted rainbows; plastered walls gleamed frost-white, and cinnabar pillars blazed like fire. Windows captured inverted reflections, and doors opened onto endless skies. Newly sculpted images took shape, their forms just descended, their expressions on the verge of speech, as if expounding the texts of the Five Thousand Words; their demeanor poised to depart, transforming scholars of the ten directions. Golden censers exuded fragrance, and jeweled parasols revolved. At first glimpse of the lamb emerging from its pen, one might still doubt its kneeling to nurse; at the initial sight of the horse white as silk, one could yet fear its neighing to the wind.

The courtyard, cleared of brambles, sprouted jade-like grasses anew; the garden, purged of weeds, burst forth with blossoms of jasper. Hills and mounds rose steeply, and towers and terraces stood grand and open. The halls of Qi’s round marshes and Wei’s square pools vied in splendor; the palace of the Transformed Man of the Western Limits stood in rivalry. Drawing in the numinous might of the Sword Pass, all converged at the imperial seat; gathering the radiant essence of Mount Emei, half entered the capital city. Smoke withered upon the azure altars, and wind carried the clear chimes of stone. Thus the Five Elders descended, and the Four Perfected all arrived. With a stroke upon the earth, rivers and lakes took form; with a pinch of soil, mountains and peaks arose. Seated, they summoned wind and rain, capable of overturning the Luo and upending the Yellow River; standing, they raised clouds and mist, able to reverse day into night. Transforming grasses and trees into armies, altering men and horses into groves, such a host could not be vanquished in a hundred battles; such a campaign against rebels could not be matched even by seven captures.

Thus when celestial calamities spread, they adhered to the principles of waxing and waning; when the cycles of fate ebbed and flowed, they accorded with the proper measures of fortune and misfortune. Zuo Ci summoned divine soldiers to lash and scatter bandits; Xu Xun commanded mighty warriors to sever and purge raging demons. Therefore, the hidden order of humanity was woven by ten thousand sages. At the cinnabar waters of Jiao Man, repeated offerings of sincere prayers bore fruit; at the Kunyang plains of Mu Ye, successive presentations of captured foes brought victory. Armor and weapons gleamed across the eight rivers, and encampments blocked the four suburbs. Battle formations stretched like clouds, and the din of war resounded like thunder. Blood spattered the sky and fell in crimson showers; sand swelled across the fields and drifted like yellow clouds. Cornered beasts snapped their fangs, and long serpents feared their tails. The people of Zheng and Cao fled in disarray; the tents of Chu stood utterly empty. Virtue balanced, righteous warriors gave their lives; qi unyielding, the royal army never aged. Day after day, the clamor of gongs and drums never ceased, yet no weariness was declared; year after year, iron armor was never doffed, yet no hardship was spoken.

Thereafter, the Phoenix City was restored to light, and the Dragon’s virtue shone resplendent. Crooked arrows upon the bowstring—what need for their piercing the moon? Long poles in hand—what purpose in their striking the heavens? Thus the thread of succession was repaired, and the raging rhinoceros was caged; the way of the martial waned, and the traitor’s head was severed by a loyal heart. Lu Shan’s fate was exhausted, and his belly was split by a gray-headed servant. Moreover, the rebellious nest had violated the celestial order, its perverse qi soaring to the skies. For seven or eight years, the chirping crickets gathered; for tens of thousands, the howling wolves assembled. The nine lands were ravaged, and the two capitals were violated. Yet by delaying punishment to spread the net of Heaven’s blessing and extending benevolent winds to temper execution, five years of stolen life were reclaimed, and all evil was eradicated in a single stroke. The tomb of Chi You was completed, his iron forehead buried deep; the throat of the Long Di was severed, and the carved halberds were forever stilled.

Such divine achievements truly relied upon the power of the Dao. Our Supreme Emperor of the Golden Watchtower, the Mysterious Origin, Heavenly Sovereign, and Great Thearch—father and mother of Heaven and Earth, master and teacher of emperors and kings—has instructed the Three Sovereigns for eighteen thousand years, presiding over the four qi and harmonizing the five movements. Uniting with the positions of state, he eternally bestowed them upon his descendants. The sacred lineage, equal to the sun and moon, has continued the eighteen thousand years.

Our High Ancestor, the Divine Yao Emperor, responded to Heaven’s mandate, bearing the mandate of fate within himself. Gazing upon the homeland, he departed not far from the immortal realm; embodying supreme virtue without claiming it, he augmented the imperial virtue to ever greater heights. Casting aside the nine vermilion tally tablets, he sealed mountains and stamped the seas; pursuing the eight transcendent chariots, he rolled through mists and wound through clouds. Bearing the banner of peace, he faced the sun and spread transformation.

Our Emperor Taizong of Civil and Martial Virtue grasped Qian and unfolded Kun, cultivating culture and pacifying arms. Great ritual knew no bounds, yet in a hundred rites he exhausted their root and origin; great sound was without tone, yet in a single note he shook past and present. Heaven bestowed courage and wisdom, enabling him to bind tigers and leopards like bundled straw; divine aid strengthened the imperial might, allowing him to measure dragons and serpents like knotted worms. Returning to truth and reverting to simplicity, he wandered in art and abided in benevolence. Taking non-binding as binding, he bound the six heroes and five hegemons; taking non-vessels as vessels, he encompassed the four insults and the nine provinces. Thereafter, contending in non-contention, warfare forever ceased; desiring in non-desire, cravings forever vanished.

Masters of the Dao gathered in throngs, and perfected lords arrived. The jujubes of An Qi took strange forms, as large as gourds; the cocoons of Yuan Ke assumed unusual shapes, piled like basins. Clad in robes for one hundred and fifty generations, he reigned for eighteen thousand years.

We now reverently consider Your Majesty, the Sagely, Divine, Wise, Benevolent, Enlightened, and Filial Emperor, who has inherited the great enterprise and unified this grand endeavor. Your heart hangs upon the Mirror of Longevity, and your body dwells in the Garden of Blessings. The imperial Dao revives at the center, and the roots of the state stand deep and firm. May you eternally safeguard the divine regalia and forever uphold the imperial order.

The Tiger’s Fang General commands eight thousand valiant warriors; the Dragon-Head Marshal leads a million crack troops, forever stabilizing the realm and forever pacifying the world. The giant turtle perished, its body blocking the seas; the long whale was slain, its warning fins piercing the heavens. Some were roasted, some burned, consuming the trees of a thousand mountains; some were boiled, some cooked, exhausting the springs of the five lakes. Purple flames reeked of blood and fat; green duckweed floated upon gore. Ominous suns fell, and comet stars plummeted; the azure canopy opened wide, and black qi vanished. The three heads of the great rebel were presented, and the nine ancestral temples of the imperial court were informed. Martial might shone through the ages, and a tower of skulls was erected upon the divine land.

As the years stretched beyond great pillars and the seasons surpassed vast floods, Heaven turned its gaze northward, preparing its divine crossbow to return to the court of Yao. The Emperor’s grace flowed eastward, borne upon a transcendent chariot to embrace the Wei watchtowers. He gathered the regional governors to bestow auspicious omens and summoned the feudal lords to the Hall of Light, reviving the lost and restoring the broken lineages.

Eight dragons descended in cloud-script, bearing celestial writ for Yu and Ji; the martial and sagely virtues of the Two Warriors illuminated the imperial power of Shang and Zhou. With the central steps leveled, the realm knew peace; with supreme virtue rightly aligned, the age flourished in harmony. Such divine merit in securing the sacred lineage arose from the sagely might of the Most High—his governance was but to sit upright in serene dignity, facing south in reverent stillness.

The Military Commissioner of Jiannan Xichuan, Grand Commandant and concurrently Chancellor, Prince of Yingchuan, Chen Jingyi—when the summer sun hung high, it blazed with awe-inspiring radiance; the star of virtue gathered eternally, its auspicious brilliance clearly marked. From afar, he breached the Turtle City to welcome the Dragon Chariot, offering a jade ladle to pour the great transformation as if turning the azure heavens, and relocating Penglai to serve as a traveling palace as though parting the blue sea. Guo Qi’s fans stirred the ranks, Qian Neng’s scratching shook the mountains and forests, Han Xiusheng amassed mosquitoes into thunder, and Yang Shigu piled fireflies to rival the sun.

Those captured were bound like rats; those executed were slaughtered like sheep. A hundred beasts danced before the court, worthy of inscription on jade tablets; the Five Ding labored beneath his banner, capable of shattering iron mountains. Even the talents of Wen Qiao and Zhuge Liang, the strategies of Xiao He and Wang Jun, could not compare. Once, Wei Gao had governed Chengdu for over twenty years, and Guo Ziyi had served as chief minister for two decades—yet when measuring their merits and benevolent governance, a single year’s surplus of nine harvests would not have been deemed excessive. Chen’s governance in Jiannan eclipsed Pei Du’s triumph in Huai’xi, all recorded in the annals to eternally illuminate his achievements.

The Commander-in-Chief of the Imperial Presence, Left Divine Strategy Army Commander-in-Chief, and Ten Armies’ Military Supervisor, Tian Lingzi—like a jade pillar of Kunlun, he alone propped up the heavens; like a golden lotus of Mount Taihua, he held the sun in his heart. Born to aid the sagely and serve the state, his talents surpassed thousands and tens of thousands, his wisdom grasped ten from one. Warm and harmonious, he assisted the Blue Emperor in fostering life; lofty in spirit, he revered the teachings of the White King. Gazing upon the imperial tally, the Five Thieves all appeared; wielding the mirror of men, myriad phenomena could not escape. His hearing discerned the unspoken; his vision perceived the unformed. Assisting the times and establishing virtue, he founded a state and secured a household, dispensing rewards and punishments without bias. The feudal lords of the Nine Kingdoms cherished his grace; the generals and marshals of the Ten Armies pledged their loyalty. In self-restraint and sincerity, he devoted his heart to the Dao, so that ancient layered structures, when respected, differed not from cinnabar terraces; old rules and standards, when upheld, ascended like the white sun. He honored the supreme lord of rites and served the ceremonial Dharma King. Eight thousand divine beasts surged forth, while rhinoceroses and elephants seemed as ants; three hundred million heavenly soldiers turned seas and mountains like duckweed.

His achievements surpassed those of the Duke of Zhou, placing him first among men; his merits outshone those of the Marquis of Zheng, leaving none to rival him. Engraved upon tripods and bells, his virtues were extolled and his deeds recorded.

The Left Vice Director of the Department of State Affairs and concurrently Chancellor, Xiao Gou—his talents and learning were unparalleled, his spirit and brilliance spanned the ages. His literary sea subdued the waves of the Huai and lakes; his mountain of learning towered above the peaks of Heng and Huo. Heaven-endowed as the nation’s blessing, his literary grace nurtured his ministerial legacy. He rectified the imperial transformation with a single stroke and upheld the great balance with eightfold integrity. Within the bounds of his teaching, he deployed countless strategic marvels; within the steps of his jade tablet, he secured the multitudes of the realm. The yellow crane cried frequently, yet even the Duke of Shao could not restrain it; the blue ox never panted, its endurance as inscrutable as good fortune.

The Minister of Personnel and concurrently Chancellor, Wei Zhaodu—a vessel of the ancestral temple, a worthy minister of the altars of soil and grain. At his post, he shone like a star; at the court, he stood firm as a mountain. His virtue, like jade tablets, was uniquely eminent; his heart, like pine and bamboo, was steadfast and true. He grounded himself in the Six Classics, rectifying customs with elegance; he harmonized the flavors of salt and plum to enrich the Dao, strengthening state and household. Though he occupied the position of the Three Excellencies, he remained empty as the ninth rank; though he bore the name of the Eight Elders, he left it unclaimed.

The Minister of War and concurrently Chancellor, Pei Jie—a steed of blessing, a heavenly colt displaying its talents. His heroic integrity spanned the age; his pure wind cleansed the world. The Silver River spanned the sky in lofty clarity; the Jade Cord hung with celestial brilliance. His learning flowed like fourfold waves; his calligraphy resembled five pines in misty rain. His upright qi chilled the court and the wilds; his straight path threaded the sheep’s gut trail. Since assuming office in the imperial domain and rising in this illustrious age, he had twice grasped the oar of Fu Yue and twice wielded the scales of Gao Yao. All honed their wisdom’s blade to sever the waist of chaos, tempered their literary spear to pierce the belly of obstinacy.

The Inner Flying Dragon Commissioner, Yang Fugong—born of an armored lineage and a distinguished clan, his fame resounded through three teachings and his clarity flowed through the nine streams. In embodying things, he stood with Zhang and Que; in pure sentiment, he surpassed Bao and Xie. Among brothers, he was one of eight dragons stirring the clouds; in discourse on classics and history, he humbled the five deer. Holding the pivot of governance through successive generations, his illustrious name spanned a hundred schools. Endowed with the immortal bearing of Wu Jizha and the quick wisdom of Kong Wenzi, his green mountains cradled jade, radiating light from every peak; his green waters held pearls, casting crystalline brilliance across the river.

The Inner Privy Councilor and Grand Chancellor with Equal Rank to the Three Dukes, Tian Yunli—his four virtues matched his position; the five stars blazed with his spirit. His wisdom, round as the moon, ever lent its light to the sun; his eloquence, flowing as a river, ever replenished the king’s sea. The Military Inspector and General of the Biaoqi Division, concurrently Commissioner of the Three Rivers, Liu Jingxuan, bore auspicious signs from past lives, his clouds of fortune unfolding in radiant hues. His bearing was peerlessly noble, his talent and capacity vast and profound. Like the jade branch of the King of Southern Yue, his phoenix soared near; like the orchid companion of the Old Man of the River, his crane’s flight was not far. His diligence in aiding and protecting was unceasing, his meritorious deeds forever inscribed.

The Right Street Majestic Daoist Master Yin Siguan, a divine immortal of towering lineage, descended from flourishing branches. He was the true heir of the Supreme Lord of Mysterious Origin and the wise descendant of the Perfected Lord of Wen Shi. At seven, he awakened to the Dao; at thirteen, he met his master. His bones, near-perfected as purple jade, would one day wander the Boarded Garden; his mastery of the Yellow Writ complete, he ascended to the Vermilion Mound. The Daoist Li Wuwei, of national origin and celestial lineage, dwelt in the fragrant shade of heaven. He delved into a thousand layers of true secrets, mastering all; he perused ten thousand scrolls of immortal scriptures, leaving none unread. Together in their master’s gate, they forged bonds as Daoist companions. In the second heaven’s phoenix cocoon, they refined spiritual qi into script; with dragon pellets of grain, they preserved youthful countenances to transcend kalpas. Adorned in starry crowns and moonlit robes, they paid homage to the Primal Emperor; mounted on rainbow reins and cloud chariots, they faced the Great Emperor. Five *hu* of golden silkworms secretly spun immortal threads; a pair of jade tablets distantly welcomed true hymns.

Since ancient times, loyal ministers and enlightened sovereigns have governed the realm to ascend to heaven, responding to the rhythms of destiny to save their age, reviving the living and completing their works. The seventy-two blessed lands and thirty-six grotto-heavens, the interconnected abodes of immortals—with Mount Qingcheng as their doors and windows, the winds and mists of true scenes untainted—with Mount Pan as their altars, could ferry the four deluded and propagate the seven divisions. At the dawn of the vast origin, kalpas stretched boundless.
In the dim and distant, the great Dao appeared—elusive, formless, beyond the reach of emperors.
The Primordial Beginning then withdrew; the Primordial Commencement followed in its wake.
The Mysterious One, the Yellow within the shell, where clear and turbid had yet to part.
Before heaven and earth, ten million years had passed.
Mountains, though older than I, fade like lightning’s flash;
seas, though vaster than I, shrink to threads of silk.
Compared with the Buddha’s teachings, the Gate of Emptiness stands forever closed;
matched against Confucian achievement, the ritual cap holds no sway.
Yet virtue shines bright, blocking all transgression; disputes dissolve, and sophistry is crushed.

Teachings adapt to the moment, responding to change without hindrance.
The Three Sovereigns grew ever wiser; the Five Emperors deepened in sagacity.
All under heaven knew peace; every living being found deliverance.
The Louguan Temple set forth its wheels; at Hangu Pass, the carriage’s traces were hung.
Taming the wild tribes and spreading transformation, extending poison’s cure and bestowing grace.
Formless form, soundless sound—
no farewell could send it off, no welcome could greet its coming.
Forced to name the unnameable, we call it by a name;
forced to label the unlabelable, we give it a label.
Above the Great Void, gold forms the city walls;
beyond the boundless dark, white jade builds the capital.
Resplendent across the six directions, embracing the eight cords of heaven,
all nations drink as one, all grains pour forth in harmony.
None can exhaust it; none can fill it.
Those who tread the shallow path dwell long in prosperity and integrity;
those who delve deep attain eternal great peace.

Fierce and blazing, its vital qi transforms into celestial warriors;
lush and vigorous, its stalwart grasses become divine soldiers.
Fire-bright blades flash like lightning; frost-edged swords gleam like rainbows.
The monstrous boar is slaughtered; the giant whale is split like a melon.
Ancient lands see their winds transformed; customs flourish.
The times grow pure.
Ages stretch distant; years stand lofty and towering.
The new palace is built, its completion to be observed for all time.

Radiant, the High Ancestor; illustrious, the sagely grandson.

Carving creation’s marrow, the sword pares primordial chaos.
Seizing sun and moon, enfolding heaven and earth.
Phoenix-tracks and phoenix-poems, tiger-strides and dragon-crouches.

within a grain of millet, Mount Kunlun may be concealed.

Illusions unravel of themselves; the polished mirror never dims.
All phenomena vanish away—only the Dao abides alone.
The Three Teachings vie for precedence—only the Dao stands supreme.
The heart harbors the Five Thieves; the realm quiets the Nine Gates.
Verdant and billowing, the admonitory mist; vast and drifting, the crossroads altar.
The Five Quarters bring tribute; the Eight Extremes race to arrive.
Chariots and foot-soldiers crowd like river-mist; taxes and levies mass like clouds.
Towering, the Jade Emperor; resplendent, the Golden Register.

Yao and Tang’s sacred thrones, Shun and Yu’s celestial emoluments.
The monstrous bandit is exterminated; the divine realm is restored.
A thousand spirits are summoned; a hundred blessings converge.
Heaven’s azure wheel turns; earth’s yellow hub revolves.
Ten jades of jade are offered; the Nine Provinces present gold.
Cold and heat pursue their course; auspicious omens intertwine.
Harm is strangled by the blade; the raging rhinoceros is sheathed in arrows.
The Han mirror is grasped; the Yin plumb-line is set to the timber.
Nine-tiered towers of jasper; five bushels of silver silkworms.
A hand points to the green ox; a body rides the white deer.
The cavern of Kuo Cang opens; the Heavenly King’s House is revealed.
The imperial root, the nation’s branch; the emperor’s clan, the celestial lineage.
The Hall of Light stands in solemn dignity; the chief minister offers wise counsel.
The Four Seas and ten thousand regions—none fail to submit.
A single rainbow arches gracefully; twin phoenixes wheel in flight.
The crane-chariot ascends the Milky Way; the simurgh soars through purple mist.
A hundred deeds accumulate; a thousand merits are fulfilled.
The cinnabar-jade tower soars, touching the Nine Heavens;
the azure-jade altar rises steeply, the Eight Immortals descend.
Beyond the great expanse lie the Isles of Peng; dragons plow the fields of magic mushrooms.
Earth possesses the Way of Humility—eastward flow the myriad rivers.
Man dwells in the Power of the Supreme—southward rule the host of worthies.
The Well of Great Life, the Spring of Eternal Longevity.
Extending the sacred succession, for eighteen thousand years.
The crane is not stained by immersion; the crow is not dyed black.
Thus it is in spontaneity; thus it is in self-attainment.
How to dispel ignorance? Discern delusion within.
How to awaken enlightenment? Cultivate the pattern within.
Like the chariot’s south-pointing needle; like the stars’ circling the North.
Manifestation and concealment are impermanent; transformation is unfathomable.
The Great Image is hard to encompass; the Two Modes grow ever more confined.
Great wisdom is hard to unfold; the Six Directions shrink narrow.
The handle of long life; the realm of eternal longevity.
At dawn, ingest the elixir-spoon; by dusk, sprout wings.
The temple offers the Three Tremblings; the winds purify ten thousand lands.
The numinous observatory is personally constructed; the host of immortals arrives in attendance.

The words are only of praise and beauty; the prose is not mere exaggeration.

The jade altar conceals wondrous signs; crimson light surges forth from the earth’s script. Of old, a mysterious talisman remained in ancient seal-script. At midnight, dragons and serpents stirred; the Six Characters shone in splendor. A year later, the wolfish rebels were pacified; the Eight Cords knew no strife. The numinous efficacy was thus revealed; the Middle Revival was inaugurated. Examining the subtle words of the imperial ancestor, manifesting the divine merit in this glorious era—should it not be inscribed at a Daoist abbey, carved in Shu’s mountains, to flow through a thousand myriad years and record our eighteen generations?

Yue Penggui, whose office is that of Inner Academician and who ranks foremost among the close ministers, has wielded his golden brush with marvelous skill, engraving it upon another mountain’s stone. His exposition is flawless; even Cai Yong would have marveled at his foresight. His composition leaves nothing unaddressed; even Cao Zhi would have found no need for solitary insight. It is fitting to carve this grand affair to authenticate this text. You are hereby ordered to erect it at the abbey in question. Upon receipt of this decree, act accordingly.

Memorial dated the eighth day of the ninth month, the fourth year of Zhonghe.

The stele inscription for the Green Ram Palace of West Sichuan is hereby concluded.
